lines.content: # hey, i'm luke, your glorified task manager :)
Luke is a chatbot that helps you keep track of your daily tasks. Think of Luke as an advanced to-do list that can help you track basic to-dos, events, as well as deadlines.
- [Marking a task as complete or incomplete: `mark`, `unmark`](#marking-a-task-as-complete-or-incomplete)
1. Ensure you have Java `17` or above installed in your Computer.
3. Copy the file to the folder you want to use as the home folder for Luke.
4. Open a command terminal, `cd` into the folder you put the jar file in, and use the `java -jar luke.jar` command to run Luke.
Luke has built-in support for 3 task types:
* `todo` The Todo task is a simple task; it has a task name and no additional data.
* `event` The Event class represents the Event task type. The Event task contains a task name, an event start time `from`, and an event end time `to`.
You can add these tasks to Luke in 2 ways:
2. Writing them inside the task list save file in `/data/Luke.txt`.
When sending tasks to Luke, each task type needs to adhere to the following formats:
The formats each task type has to be stored in within `Luke.txt` are as follows:
Filters a task list for tasks that match the provided search criteria.
Shows a list of all the tasks in the task list.
### Marking a task as complete or incomplete
Toggles the completion status of a task identified by its number.
If the task was unmarked, it will be marked as complete.
If the task was already marked as complete, it will be unmarked.
Removes a task from the list using its index number.
Example: `delete 2` (removes the second task in the list)
To exit Luke, all you need to do is to enter `bye`. Bye, Luke!
Any tasks you give Luke will be saved in the hard disk automatically after any command that modifies the list.
You will not need to save the task list manually.
All saved tasks will be accessible the next time you run Luke.

Luke's task list is automatically saved as a `.txt` file at `[JAR file location]/data/Luke.txt`. You may modify the task list directly if you like, but tasks need to follow a specific format to be processed by Luke.
Please edit the data only if you are sure you can update it correctly, otherwise Luke may not work as designed.
Format tasks have to be stored in within `Luke.txt`:
* For `todo` tasks: `<completion status> | todo | <todo task name>`
* For `deadline` tasks: `<completion status> | deadline <task name> by <deadline date>`
* For `event` tasks: `<completion status> | event | <task name> | from: <start time> to: <end time>`

| Add task | `todo `
e.g., `todo travel to coruscant`

`deadline /by `
e.g. `deadline lightsaber presentation slides /by 28/07/2024 18:00`

`event /from /to `
e.g. `event senate meeting /from Friday 2pm /to 3pm`|

X | event | dinner with obi-wan from Monday 8pm to 9pm
- | deadline | check in on padawans by Sep 20 2024, 18:00
# hey, i'm luke, your glorified task manager :)
Luke is a chatbot that helps you keep track of your daily tasks. Think of Luke as an advanced to-do list that can help you track basic to-dos, events, as well as deadlines.
- [Marking a task as complete or incomplete: `mark`, `unmark`](#marking-a-task-as-complete-or-incomplete)
1. Ensure you have Java `17` or above installed in your Computer.
3. Copy the file to the folder you want to use as the home folder for Luke.
4. Open a command terminal, `cd` into the folder you put the jar file in, and use the `java -jar luke.jar` command to run Luke.
Luke has built-in support for 3 task types:
* `todo` The Todo task is a simple task; it has a task name and no additional data.
* `event` The Event class represents the Event task type. The Event task contains a task name, an event start time `from`, and an event end time `to`.
You can add these tasks to Luke in 2 ways:
2. Writing them inside the task list save file in `/data/Luke.txt`.
When sending tasks to Luke, each task type needs to adhere to the following formats:
The formats each task type has to be stored in within `Luke.txt` are as follows:
Filters a task list for tasks that match the provided search criteria.
Shows a list of all the tasks in the task list.
### Marking a task as complete or incomplete
Toggles the completion status of a task identified by its number.
If the task was unmarked, it will be marked as complete.
If the task was already marked as complete, it will be unmarked.
Removes a task from the list using its index number.
Example: `delete 2` (removes the second task in the list)
To exit Luke, all you need to do is to enter `bye`. Bye, Luke!
Any tasks you give Luke will be saved in the hard disk automatically after any command that modifies the list.
You will not need to save the task list manually.
All saved tasks will be accessible the next time you run Luke.

Luke's task list is automatically saved as a `.txt` file at `[JAR file location]/data/Luke.txt`. You may modify the task list directly if you like, but tasks need to follow a specific format to be processed by Luke.
Please edit the data only if you are sure you can update it correctly, otherwise Luke may not work as designed.
Format tasks have to be stored in within `Luke.txt`:
* For `todo` tasks: `<completion status> | todo | <todo task name>`
* For `deadline` tasks: `<completion status> | deadline <task name> by <deadline date>`
* For `event` tasks: `<completion status> | event | <task name> | from: <start time> to: <end time>`

| Add task | `todo `
e.g., `todo travel to coruscant`

`deadline /by `
e.g. `deadline lightsaber presentation slides /by 28/07/2024 18:00`

`event /from /to `
e.g. `event senate meeting /from Friday 2pm /to 3pm`|
* The {@code DialogBox} class represents a custom JavaFX component that displays a dialog box with text
* and an accompanying image (the user is represented by an Ewok and Luke is represented by Luke Skywalker.)
* It is used in Luke to show both user messages and Luke's responses.
* This class is designed to load the layout from an FXML file and includes methods to format the dialog
* box, such as flipping the display to show either the user dialog or Luke's dialog.
* Flips the dialog box such that the ImageView is on the left and text on the right.
public static DialogBox getUserDialog(String text, Image img) {
public static DialogBox getLukeDialog(String text, Image img) {
* (From the SE-EDU JavaFX tutorial) A launcher class to workaround classpath issues.
* The {@code Luke} class is the main entry point for Luke.
* It provides a method to process user input and return appropriate responses by delegating
* the handling of input to the {@link Ui} class.
* A GUI for Luke built on FXML.
* The {@code LukeUiWindow} class represents the main user interface (UI) window for interacting with Luke.
* This class is responsible for handling user inputs, displaying Luke's responses, and managing the dialog flow
* between the user and the application.

*
  • Displays welcome messages and instructions for the user

*
  • Handles the user's input and provides responses from the {@link Luke} instance

*
  • Loads previous task data from storage upon initialisation

*
  • Allows the user to create a new save file if one is missing

* The save data is stored in a file at a path specified by {@link Constants#FILE_PATH}.

* Represents the user interface of the bot. This class is responsible for handling user input and processing
* commands to read/write from/to the task list.
* This class supports the following command keywords:

*
  • {@code mark} marks tasks that are complete

*
  • {@code unmark} unmarks tasks that are incomplete

*
  • {@code find} returns a filtered version of the task list based on search criteria

*
  • {@code delete} deletes items from a list
private static TaskList taskList = new TaskList();

* @return The message to be printed on the UI that corresponds with the
* Determines which procs to invoke depending on the command word.
* @param command command word and its associated args
* @param isLoadingFromDisk true if the command was loaded from save data
public static String handleCommand(Command command, boolean isLoadingFromDisk) {
return "here's everything that's in your list:\n" + taskList.printList();
* Toggles the completion status of a task identified by its number.
* If the task was unmarked, it will be marked as complete.
* If the task was already marked, it will be unmarked.
* @param command A Command object containing the mark/unmark command and the task number argument.
* @return A String message that confirms the marking/unmarking of the input task.
* @throws NumberFormatException If the provided task number is not a valid integer.
* @throws IndexOutOfBoundsException If the task number is out of range.
* Deletes a task from the task list.
* @param command The "delete" command word and its arg -- the index of the relevant task in the task list
return "alright i've purged this task for you:\n"
* Processes a 'find' command by filtering a taskList for tasks that match the provided search criteria.
* The tasks are filtered based on the arguments of the {@link Command} and returned
* as a formatted string that lists all matching tasks as a numbered list.
* The method uses the {@link TaskList#findTasks(String)} to retrieve a list of tasks
* that match the search criteria, then formats them into a numbered list.
* @param command The {@link Command} object containing the search criteria in its arguments.
*                The command's arguments are used to filter tasks from the task list.
* @return A formatted string containing the matching tasks.
return "here are the matching tasks in your list:\n" + filteredList;

public static String handleAddTask(Command command, boolean isLoadingFromDisk) {

* The {@code Command} class represents a user command in Luke.
* It contains the main components of a command, including the command word,
* associated arguments, and a mark indicating the task's completion status (if applicable).
* Constructs a {@code Command} object with a mark, command word, and arguments.
* @param mark The mark indicating task status (e.g. "X" for done, "-" for not done).
* @param command The command word representing the user's action (e.g. "mark", "unmark", "find").
* @param args The arguments associated with the command (e.g. task description, index).
public Command(String mark, String command, String args) {
* The {@code Constants} class stores constants that are reused in different parts of the Luke codebase.

*
  • INDENT is used to indent task lists in Luke dialog boxes.

*
  • TASK_TYPES is a string list that stores the names of the different task types.

*
  • FILE_PATH is the file path of the save data file which Luke will read from and write to.
public static final String BAD_COMMAND = "hmmmm...the command doesn't really make sense to me. try again?";
public static final String BYE_MESSAGE = "yeah bye bye to you too human being <3";
public static final List<String> TASK_TYPES = List.of(new String[]{"todo", "event", "deadline"});
public static final String DUPLICATE_TASK_MESSAGE = "hey, that task already exists in this list. "
* The {@code Deadline} class represents the Deadline task type. The Deadline task contains a task name,
* The task description is shown in the format:
* where the "D" represents a "Deadline" task, and the "X" (or blank) represents the completion status.
* The save format for a Deadline task is as follows:
* X | deadline | Task Name by Deadline Date
* where "X" represents that the task is marked as done, and "-" indicates it is not done.

* Constructs a new {@code Deadline} task with the specified task name, deadline, and completion status.

* @param deadline The due date and time for the task.
* @param isDone   The completion status of the deadline task. {@code true} if the task is completed.
public Deadline(String taskName, String deadline, boolean isDone) {
* Parses the given deadline string into a formatted date or date-time string.
* This method tries to parse the input string using a series of predefined {@link DateTimeFormatter}
* patterns. It first attempts to parse the string as a {@link LocalDateTime} (i.e., containing both
* date and time). If none of the date-time patterns match, it then attempts to parse the string as
* If the input string is successfully parsed as a {@code LocalDateTime}, it will be formatted
* using {@code "MMM d yyyy, HH:mm"} (e.g., "Sep 23 2024, 14:30"). If the input string is parsed
* as a {@code LocalDate}, it will be formatted using {@code "MMM d yyyy"} (e.g., "Sep 23 2024").
* @param deadline The input string representing the deadline in various date or date-time formats.
* @return The formatted deadline string if parsing is successful. Otherwise, it will return the unformatted string.

// Ignore and try the next formatter
// 2. If no LocalDateTime format worked, try parsing as a LocalDate (date-only)
// Ignore and try the next formatter
// If the deadline string doesn't match any format, return the unformatted deadline.
* The {@code Event} class represents the Event task type. The Event task contains a task name, an event start time
* {@code from}, and an event end time {@code to}.
* The task description is shown in the format:
* [E][X] Task Name (from: Start Time to: End Time)
* where the "E" represents a "Event" task, and the "X" (or blank) represents the completion status.
* The save format for an Event task is as follows:
* X | event | Task Name | from: Start Time to: End Time
* where "X" represents that the task is marked as done, and "-" indicates it is not done.
* Constructs a new {@code Event} task with the specified task name, start time, end time, and completion status.
* @param taskName The name of the event task.
* @param from The start time of the event.
* @param to The end time of the event.
* @param isDone The completion status of the event. {@code true} if the event is completed.
public Event(String taskName, String from, String to, boolean isDone) {

return "your list has " + listSize + " item now.\n";
return "your list has " + listSize + " items now.\n";

* @throws UnknownCommandException Thrown when any command apart from the task types are passed to the function.
public String addToList(String command, String taskDetails, boolean isMarked, boolean isLoadingFromDisk)

* Filters the task list to include only tasks that contain the specified search term.
* The search matches substrings within task descriptions.

* Each task is displayed with an index number followed by its description.

* Two tasks are considered duplicates if they have the same name and are of the same type.
* @param newTask The task that will be checked for duplication

Deadline dl = new Deadline("return book", "2/12/2020 15:00", false);
assertEquals("- | deadline | return book by Dec 2 2020, 15:00\n", dl.taskInSaveData());
Deadline dl = new Deadline("return book", "2/12/2020 15:00", true);
assertEquals("X | deadline | return book by Dec 2 2020, 15:00\n", dl.taskInSaveData());
Event event = new Event("project meeting", "6/7/2020 2pm", "4pm", false);
assertEquals("- | event | project meeting from 6/7/2020 2pm to 4pm\n", event.taskInSaveData());
Event event = new Event("project meeting", "6/7/2020 2pm", "4pm", true);
assertEquals("X | event | project meeting from 6/7/2020 2pm to 4pm\n", event.taskInSaveData());
